data.title: Syllogisms
data.statement:
A syllogism (Greek: συλλογισμός syllogismos, "conclusion, inference") is a kind of logical argument that applies deductive reasoning to arrive at a conclusion based on two (in this case) or more propositions (ie premises) that are asserted or assumed to be true. Here is a typical syllogism:

all men are mortal
all Greeks are men
therefore, all Greeks are mortal

In this puzzle you will deal only with categorical syllogisms. 

A valid syllogism is one whose conclusion logically follows from its premises. A syllogism can be valid but not sound (ie does not make sense to people) as in :

Some bears are venusians.
All venusians are arachnids.
Therefore some arachnids are bears.

Your goal is to:
1 - Read a syllogism
3 - Parse it
3 - Evaluate it 

Identifying the type of the premises and conclusions and the relation between the various [[subjects]] and [[predicates]] will let you decide wether the syllogism is {{VALID}} or {{INVALID}}.

All provided syllogism are syntaxically correct (ie the {{and}} and {{therefore}} keywords are well placed, the {{not}} keyword will not appear with a {{all}} or {{no}} keyword, etc ...)


Each syllogysm is structured as follows:
[[majorPremise]] {{and}} [[minorPremise]] {{therefore}} [[conclusion]]

[[majorPremise]], [[minorPremise]] and [[conclusion]] are structured as follow:
{{all|no|some}} [[subject]] [[verb]] [{{not}}] [[predicate]]

[[subject]] and [[predicate]] are single different words on a given premise/conclusion. You do not have to care for singular or plural : matching terms will always be provided with the same form. Also as a hint, the [[verb]] does not have any importance in this exercise, only the opening word ({{all}}, {{no}}, {{some}}), [[subject]] and [[predicate]] and when applicable the {{not}}. 

The {{not}} keyword may only appear with a {{some}} keyword (ie : "some boat have sails", "some apples are not green")

The {{and}} and {{therefore}} keywords (surrounded by spaces) will not appear in the premises.

A syllogism (Greek: συλλογισμός syllogismos, "conclusion, inference") is a kind of logical argument that applies deductive reasoning to arrive at a conclusion based on two (in this case) or more propositions (ie premises) that are asserted or assumed to be true. Here is a typical syllogism:

Therefore some arachnids are bears.

Your goal is to:
1 - Read a syllogism
3 - Parse it
3 - Evaluate it

Identifying the type of the premises and conclusions and the relation between the various subjects and predicates will let you decide wether the syllogism is VALID or INVALID.

Each syllogysm is structured as follows:
majorPremise and minorPremise therefore conclusion

majorPremise, minorPremise and conclusion are structured as follow:

subject and predicate are single different words on a given premise/conclusion. You do not have to care for singular or plural : matching terms will always be provided with the same form. The and and therefore keywords (surrounded by spaces) will not appear in the premises.
Input
Line 1 : nbSyllogisms
next nbSyllogisms lines : syllogism

where :
- syllogism : majorPremise and minorPremise therefore conclusion
- premise/conclusion : all|no|some subject verb [not] predicate
Output
either VALID or INVALID for each conclusion, each on a line with no empty lines at all.
Constraints
1 <= nbSyllogisms < 100
1 <= any line's length < 256

all humans are mortal and all greeks are humans therefore no greeks are mortal
